sentences.content: think again the power of knowing what you don't know by Adam grant part 5

what do you want to do when you grow up this question gets thrown at us as kids we have a lot of hopes and dreams but sometimes our efforts just don't meet our expectations the expectations might come from family friends or even Society in chasing these expectations a person might set long-term goals but when they aren't able to achieve them they continue pushing towards the goal without realizing it may be time for a little rethinking

maybe there are other routes they could take instead psychologists called this escalation of commitment where a person is so committed to their goal that they don't realize the alternative options available to them

as shown in the book rethinking is like revising a hypothesis that didn't work in an experiment we rethink things we are curious about because we aren't forced to believe in them rethinking results from open ended questions that make us reconsider are embedded stereotypes and the decisions we have made we thinkers have changed the course of history because they have figured out that their original strategies were either too safe or mundane for anything new to happen they challenge the status quo without preaching their beliefs Prosecuting anyone who stands in their way or politicking their way for support

rethinking is not about asking why but how it's realizing that there are many sides to an argument that nothing is black-and-white and that even the most stubborn individuals can change their opinions history gives us facts but we alter them and piece them together in an ever-changing puzzle that's what rethinking requires to think like a scientist

zh-TW.content: 亞當‧格蘭特《重新思考：能知你所不知的力量》，第五部分。
我們小時候總會遇到突然丟出來的一句問題：「你長大後想做什麼？」
我們有很多的期望和夢想，但有時我們的努力並不能滿足我們的期待。
這些期待可能來自家庭、朋友，甚至來自社會。
在努力達成這些期待的過程中，人們可能會設下長期目標，但當我們沒辦法達成時，它們還是默默地推著我們要去完成那些事情，而我們卻沒想到可以重新思考一下情況，其實也許還有其他我們可以走的替代道路。
心理學家將這個情形稱為「承諾升級」，亦即人們過於投入在他們的目標上，以致他們沒有想到還有其他替代選項可供選擇。
書中說到，重新思考就像是去修正在實驗中沒有起效用的假說。
因為沒有被逼迫去相信那些我們感到好奇的事物，我們才能進行重新思考。
重新思考開放式問題產出的結果能讓我們重新檢視深植我們腦中的刻板印象以及我們所做的決定。
重新思考的實踐者已改變了歷史的進程，因為他們已認知到原有的策略不是過於安全，就是過於平庸，而這都無助於新事物的產生。
他們挑戰現狀，但不會佈道式地宣揚他們的信念，也不會用起訴質詢的方式對待阻礙他們的人或是像在競選般拉攏別人來獲得支持。
重新思考要問的是「如何達成」，而不是「為什麼這樣」。
重新思考是能了解到一個爭論主題有很多個面向，沒有任何事情是非黑即白的，它甚至能讓最固執的人改變他們的想法。
歷史給了我們事實，但我們能在不斷變化的謎團中去改變它們、拼湊它們，而這就是重新思考所需具備的——像科學家一樣思考。

en-US.content: Think Again: The Power of Knowing What You Don’t Know by Adam Grant – Part 5
“What do you want to do when you grow up?” This question gets thrown at us as kids.
We have a lot of hopes and dreams, but sometimes our efforts just don’t meet our expectations.
The expectations might come from family, friends, or even society.

In chasing these expectations, a person might set long-term goals, but when they aren't able to achieve them, they continue pushing towards the goal without realizing it may be time for a little rethinking. Maybe there are other routes they could take instead.
Psychologists call this “escalation of commitment,” where a person is so committed to their goal that they don’t realize the alternative options available to them.
As shown in the book, rethinking is like revising a hypothesis that didn't work in an experiment.
We rethink things we are curious about because we aren't forced to believe in them.
Rethinking results from open-ended questions that make us reconsider our embedded stereotypes and the decisions we have made.
Rethinkers have changed the course of history because they have figured out that their original strategies were either too safe or mundane for anything new to happen.
They challenge the status quo without preaching their beliefs, prosecuting anyone who stands in their way or politicking their way for support.
Rethinking is not about asking “why” but “how.”
It’s realizing that there are many sides to an argument, that nothing is black and white, and that even the most stubborn individuals can change their opinions.
History gives us facts, but we alter them and piece them together in an ever-changing puzzle. That’s what rethinking requires—to think like a scientist.
